metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: JavaScript Function Definitions
JavaScript functions are defined with the function keyword.
content.html: JavaScript functions are defined with the function keyword.

content.text: You can use a function declaration or a function expression .
content.html: You can use a function declaration or a function expression.

content.text: Function Declarations
Earlier in this tutorial, you learned that functions are declared with the following syntax:
content.html: Earlier in this tutorial, you learned that functions are declared with the following syntax:

content.code_html:
function functionName(parameters) {
  // code to be executed
 }

content.text: Declared functions are not executed immediately. They are "saved for later use", and will be executed later, when they are invoked (called upon).
content.html: Declared functions are not executed immediately. They are "saved for later use", and will be executed later, when they are invoked (called upon).

syntaxHighlighting.text:
function myFunction(a, b) {
   return a * b;}

content.code:
function myFunction(a, b) {
return a * b;}

syntax_highlighting.text:
function myFunction(a, b) {
   return a * b;}

content.code_html:
function myFunction(a, b) {
  return a * b;
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
function myFunction(a, b) {
   return a * b;}

content.text: Semicolons are used to separate executable JavaScript statements. Since a function declaration is not an executable statement, it is not common to end it with a semicolon.
content.html:
Semicolons are used to separate executable JavaScript statements.
Since a function declaration is not an executable statement, it is not common to end it with a semicolon.

content.text: Function Expressions
A JavaScript function can also be defined using an expression .
content.html: A JavaScript function can also be defined using an expression.

content.text: A function expression can be stored in a variable:
content.html: A function expression can be stored in a variable:

syntaxHighlighting.text: const x = function (a, b) {return a * b};

content.code: const x = function (a, b) {return a * b};

syntax_highlighting.text: const x = function (a, b) {return a * b};

content.code_html: const x = function (a, b) {return a * b};

syntax_highlighting_data.text: const x = function (a, b) {return a * b};

content.text: After a function expression has been stored in a variable, the variable can be used as a function:
content.html: After a function expression has been stored in a variable, the variable can be used as a function:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
const x = function (a, b) {return a * b};
let z = x(4, 3);

content.code:
const x = function (a, b) {return a * b};
let z = x(4, 3);

syntax_highlighting.text:
const x = function (a, b) {return a * b};
let z = x(4, 3);

content.code_html:
const x = function (a, b) {return a * b};
let z = x(4, 3);

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
const x = function (a, b) {return a * b};
let z = x(4, 3);

content.text: The function above is actually an anonymous function (a function without a name).
content.html: The function above is actually an anonymous function (a function without a name).

content.text: Functions stored in variables do not need function names. They are always invoked (called) using the variable name.
content.html: Functions stored in variables do not need function names. They are always invoked (called) using the variable name.

content.text: The function above ends with a semicolon because it is a part of an executable statement.
content.html: The function above ends with a semicolon because it is a part of an executable statement.

content.text: The Function() Constructor
As you have seen in the previous examples, JavaScript functions are defined with the function keyword.
content.html: As you have seen in the previous examples, JavaScript functions are defined with the function keyword.

content.text: Functions can also be defined with a built-in JavaScript function constructor called Function() .
content.html: Functions can also be defined with a built-in JavaScript function constructor called Function().

syntaxHighlighting.text:
const myFunction = new Function("a", "b", "return a * b");
let x = myFunction(4, 3);

content.code:
const myFunction = new Function("a", "b", "return a * b");
let x = myFunction(4, 3);

syntax_highlighting.text:
const myFunction = new Function("a", "b", "return a * b");
let x = myFunction(4, 3);

content.code_html:
const myFunction = new Function("a", "b", "return a * b");

let x = myFunction(4, 3);

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
const myFunction = new Function("a", "b", "return a * b");
let x = myFunction(4, 3);

content.text: You actually don't have to use the function constructor. The example above is the same as writing:
content.html: You actually don't have to use the function constructor. The example above is the same as writing:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
const myFunction = function (a, b) {return a * b};
let x = myFunction(4, 3);

content.code:
const myFunction = function (a, b) {return a * b};
let x = myFunction(4, 3);

syntax_highlighting.text:
const myFunction = function (a, b) {return a * b};
let x = myFunction(4, 3);

content.code_html:
const myFunction = function (a, b) {return a * b};

let x = myFunction(4, 3);

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
const myFunction = function (a, b) {return a * b};
let x = myFunction(4, 3);

content.text: Most of the time, you can avoid using the new keyword in JavaScript.
content.html: Most of the time, you can avoid using the new keyword in JavaScript.

content.text: Function Hoisting
Earlier in this tutorial, you learned about "hoisting" ( JavaScript Hoisting ).
content.html: Earlier in this tutorial, you learned about "hoisting" (JavaScript Hoisting).

content.text: Hoisting is JavaScript's default behavior of moving declarations to the top of the current scope.
content.html: Hoisting is JavaScript's default behavior of moving declarations to the top of the current scope.

content.text: Hoisting applies to variable declarations and to function declarations.
content.html: Hoisting applies to variable declarations and to function declarations.

content.text: Because of this, JavaScript functions can be called before they are declared:
content.html: Because of this, JavaScript functions can be called before they are declared:

content.code_html:
myFunction(5);

function myFunction(y) {
  return y * y;
}

content.text: Functions defined using an expression are not hoisted.
content.html: Functions defined using an expression are not hoisted.

content.text: Self-Invoking Functions
Function expressions can be made "self-invoking".
content.html: Function expressions can be made "self-invoking".

content.text: A self-invoking expression is invoked (started) automatically, without being called.
content.html: A self-invoking expression is invoked (started) automatically, without being called.

content.text: Function expressions will execute automatically if the expression is followed by ().
content.html: Function expressions will execute automatically if the expression is followed by ().

content.text: You cannot self-invoke a function declaration.
content.html: You cannot self-invoke a function declaration.

content.text: You have to add parentheses around the function to indicate that it is a function expression:
content.html: You have to add parentheses around the function to indicate that it is a function expression:

content.code_html:
(function () {
  let x = "Hello!!";  // I will invoke myself
 })();

content.text: The function above is actually an anonymous self-invoking function (function without name).
content.html: The function above is actually an anonymous self-invoking function (function without name).

content.text: Functions Can Be Used as Values
JavaScript functions can be used as values:
content.html: JavaScript functions can be used as values:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
function myFunction(a, b) {  return a * b;}
let x = myFunction(4, 3);

content.code:
function myFunction(a, b) {  return a * b;}
let x = myFunction(4, 3);

syntax_highlighting.text:
function myFunction(a, b) {  return a * b;}
let x = myFunction(4, 3);

content.code_html:
function myFunction(a, b) {
  return a * b;
}

let x = myFunction(4, 3);

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
function myFunction(a, b) {  return a * b;}
let x = myFunction(4, 3);

content.text: JavaScript functions can be used in expressions:
content.html: JavaScript functions can be used in expressions:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
function myFunction(a, b) {  return a * b;}
let x = myFunction(4, 3) * 2;

content.code:
function myFunction(a, b) {  return a * b;}
let x = myFunction(4, 3) * 2;

syntax_highlighting.text:
function myFunction(a, b) {  return a * b;}
let x = myFunction(4, 3) * 2;

content.code_html:
function myFunction(a, b) {
  return a * b;
}

let x = myFunction(4, 3) * 2;

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
function myFunction(a, b) {  return a * b;}
let x = myFunction(4, 3) * 2;

content.text: Functions are Objects
The typeof operator in JavaScript returns "function" for functions.
content.html: The typeof operator in JavaScript returns "function" for functions.

content.text: But, JavaScript functions can best be described as objects.
content.html: But, JavaScript functions can best be described as objects.

content.text: JavaScript functions have both properties and methods .
content.html: JavaScript functions have both properties and methods.

content.text: The arguments.length property returns the number of arguments received when the function was invoked:
content.html: The arguments.length property returns the number of arguments received when the function was invoked:

content.code_html:
function myFunction(a, b) {
  return arguments.length;
}

content.text: The toString() method returns the function as a string:
content.html: The toString() method returns the function as a string:

syntaxHighlighting.text: function myFunction(a, b) {  return a * b;}let text = myFunction.toString();

content.code: function myFunction(a, b) {  return a * b;}let text = myFunction.toString();

syntax_highlighting.text: function myFunction(a, b) {  return a * b;}let text = myFunction.toString();

content.code_html:
function myFunction(a, b) {
  return a * b;
}

let text = myFunction.toString();

syntax_highlighting_data.text: function myFunction(a, b) {  return a * b;}let text = myFunction.toString();

content.text: A function defined as the property of an object, is called a method to the object. A function designed to create new objects, is called an object constructor.
content.html:
A function defined as the property of an object, is called a method to the object.
A function designed to create new objects, is called an object constructor.

content.text: Arrow Functions
Arrow functions allows a short syntax for writing function expressions.
content.html: Arrow functions allows a short syntax for writing function expressions.

content.text: You don't need the function keyword, the return keyword, and the curly brackets .
content.html: You don't need the function keyword, the return keyword, and the curly brackets.

content.code_html:
// ES5
 var x = function(x, y) {
  return x * y;
}

// ES6
 const x = (x, y) => x * y;

content.text: Arrow functions do not have their own this . They are not well suited for defining object methods .
content.html: Arrow functions do not have their own this. They are not well suited for defining object methods.

content.text: Arrow functions are not hoisted. They must be defined before they are used.
content.html: Arrow functions are not hoisted. They must be defined before they are used.

content.text: Using const is safer than using var , because a function expression is always constant value.
content.html: Using const is safer than using var, because a function expression is always constant value.

content.text: You can only omit the return keyword and the curly brackets if the function is a single statement. Because of this, it might be a good habit to always keep them:
content.html: You can only omit the return keyword and the curly brackets if the function is a single statement. Because of this, it might be a good habit to always keep them:

syntaxHighlighting.text: const x = (x, y) => { return x * y };

content.code: const x = (x, y) => { return x * y };

syntax_highlighting.text: const x = (x, y) => { return x * y };

content.code_html: const x = (x, y) => { return x * y };

syntax_highlighting_data.text: const x = (x, y) => { return x * y };

content.text: Arrow functions are not supported in IE11 or earlier.
content.html: Arrow functions are not supported in IE11 or earlier.
